abstract: Report by Democrats on House Natural Resources Committee finds countries generally fail to use proceeds from trophy hunting to fund broader conservation efforts, contradicting advocates' long-held justification for killing threatened wildlife; experts say 2015 killing of lion named Cecil in Zimbabwe prompted closer scrutiny of system governing sport hunting globally.
lead_paragraph: A report by Democrats on the House Natural Resources Committee challenges claims that revenue from big-game hunts helps broader conservation efforts.

headline.main: Trophy Hunting Fees Do Little to Help Threatened Species, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Report Finds Hunting Fees Do Not Help Conservation

snippet: A report by Democrats on the House Natural Resources Committee challenges claims that revenue from big-game hunts helps broader conservation efforts.
